title: May 15
description:
Milo's had a hard time keeping a consistent educational experience this year. After all the strikes this Fall, his first teacher went on maternity leave over Christmas, and now.... the substitute's disappeared!

There's a new teacher who claims to only be temporary, but the school hasn't given any word of where the old one got off to. At least the new one's a man, and Milo's never been taught by a dude. He's enjoying the experience.

And one day this week, there was a substitute for the substitute's substitute.

To prepare the kids for an apparent life without teachers, Dean has been playing math games. The current one revolves around a bunch of pirates, and a typical question goes like this: "If Captain Yarr claims 10 pieces of gold from the plundered ship and the other 10 pirates each get 5 pieces, how much treasure was in the ship's coffers?

Or: Ten pirates board a merchant ship crewed by 10 sailors. In the ensuing knife fight three people are killed on each side, and one pirate loses two fingers. How many living are left on deck when the merchant captain invokes the right of parley? And how many fingers do they have between them?

We've discovered that Milo's a genius at pirate math.

children.title: Sweet Baboo
children.description: Babushka's here and our roses are magnificent!

children.title: Super Munchkins
children.description: Dean had this idea:  what if you threw a Munchkins party and actual thieves, warriors and gnomes showed up?

children.title: Bard v Thief
children.description: A gnomic bard threatens an elven thief with his magical tambourine, while a dwarven warrior looks on in amusement.

children.title: Victory!
children.description: "VICTORY IS MINE" thunders the gnomic bard.

children.title: Le Bourget
children.description:
Le Bourget, a business jet airport just outside Paris, also plays host to France's Air and Space Museum.

Since it's out of the way, we DIDN'T have to contend with the hordes of tourists now clogging central Paris. Damn foreigners.

children.title: Dog is my Copilot
children.description: Le Bourget has an excellent selection of interactive stuff for kids, such as this flight simulator.

children.title: Space Monkey
children.description: Milo defies gravity in the space station's rotation chamber.

children.title: Helmet Not Included
children.description: He's not bored, he's just waiting for the rotation chamber to dump him on his brain box again.

children.title: Supersonic People Bus
children.description:
Dean's always been fascinated with the French-built (ok the British might have had a teensy bit to do with it) Concorde, the discontinued supersonic people mover.

"Why!?" he cries. "Why weren't there more rich people in the world who wanted to fly Mach 2.02 between New York and Paris!?"

children.title: Size Matters
children.description: That Concorde sure has some big'uns.

children.title: To Infinity And Beyond
children.description:
The first version of the Ariane, a French-built launch vehicle for communications satellites.

It's no Apollo, but that'll do, pig. That'll do.

children.title: Bercy
children.description:
You know what? We feel like we're running out of time in Paris, but not even close to running out of new places to explore.

This is the Bercy neighborhood. It's got it all: a giant quasi Japanese park with cool mazes, an English pub that makes delicious bacon cheeseburgers, and a Starbucks for those of us with *ahem* urges.

children.title: Skatopia
children.description:
Bercy also has this most excellent skater's paradise.

Felix: "It looks so dangerous!". Milo: "Can we go home and get my scooter?"
